panels.description: Long-running transactions can consume CPU resources that can lead to high CPU utilization.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT pid, usename, datname, query, now() - xact_start as duration 
FROM pg_stat_activity  
WHERE pid <> pg_backend_pid() and state IN ('idle in transaction', 'active') 
ORDER BY duration DESC;

panels.title: Long-running transactions

panels.description: Helps identify queries that consume I/O on the server

targets.rawSql:
SELECT userid::regrole, dbid, query, calls
FROM pg_stat_statements 
ORDER BY blk_read_time + blk_write_time desc  
LIMIT 5;

panels.title: Identify high I/O utilization

panels.description: A large number of connections to the database is also another issue that might lead to increased CPU and memory utilization.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT state, count(*)  
FROM  pg_stat_activity   
WHERE pid <> pg_backend_pid()  
GROUP BY 1 ORDER BY 1;

panels.title: Total number of connections and number connections by state

panels.description: Keeping table statistics up to date helps improve query performance. Monitor whether regular autovacuuming is being carried out.

targets.rawSql:
select schemaname,relname,n_dead_tup,n_live_tup,last_vacuum,last_analyze,last_autovacuum,last_autoanalyze 
from pg_stat_all_tables where n_live_tup > 0;

panels.title: Monitoring vacuum and table stats

panels.description: It provides a resultset sorted by the mist CPU-intensive queries in descending order

targets.rawSql:
Select pss.userid, pss.dbid, pd.datname as db_name, pss.total_time,
        pss.calls,
        pss.mean_time as mean,
        round((100 * (pss.total_time) / sum ((pss.total_time)::numeric) OVER ()) :: numeric, 2) as cpu_portion_pctg, pss.query
From pg_stat_statements as pss, pg_database as pd
where pd.oid = pss.dbid
order by pss.total_time
desc limit 30;

panels.title: How much each query in each database uses the CPU

panels.description: the top frequent PostgreSQL queries run the following SQL query

targets.rawSql:
with
a as (select dbid, queryid, query, calls s from pg_stat_statements),
b as (select dbid, queryid, query, calls s from pg_stat_statements, pg_sleep(1))
select
        pd.datname as db_name, 
        substr(a.query, 1, 2048) as the_query, 
        sum(b.s-a.s) as runs_per_second
from a, b, pg_database pd
where 
  a.dbid= b.dbid 
and 
  a.queryid = b.queryid 
and 
  pd.oid=a.dbid
group by 1, 2
order by 3 desc;

panels.title: Running frequent SQL queries
Identify root causes (Use if has accident)

panels.description: Provide the size of database postgreSQL in currently

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  datname as database_name,
  pg_database_size(datname)/1024/1024 as size
FROM
  pg_database
WHERE
  datistemplate = false;

panels.title: Size of a PostgreSQL Database

panels.description: The PostgreSQL cache area is known as shared_buffers, which acts as the database layer cache on top of the cache provided by the operating system

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  sum(heap_blks_read) as reads,
  sum(heap_blks_hit) as hits,
  ROUND(
    sum(heap_blks_hit) / (sum(heap_blks_hit) + sum(heap_blks_read)),
    4
  ) as hit_ratio
FROM
  pg_statio_user_tables;

panels.title: Database Cache-Hit Ratios

panels.description: Total time of queries, There one queries give for running on whole system

names:
WITH "s" AS (
            INSERT INTO "hangfire"."state" ("jobid", "name", "reason", "createdat", "data")
            VALUES ($1, $2, $3, $4, $5) RETURNING "id"
        )
        UPDATE "hangfire"."job" "j"
        SET "stateid" = s."id", "statename" = $2
        FROM "s"
        WHERE "j"."id" = $6 percent

SELECT t0."Id", t0."HasInactiveParent", t0."HierarchyPath", t0."Name", t0."OrganizationStatus", t0."ParentOrganizationalUnitId", t0."RootId", t1."Id", t1."CompanyId", t1."CreatedBy", t1."CreatedDate", t1."LastUpdatedBy", t1."LastUpdatedDate", t1."TimeZone", t1."AutoLock_IsEnable", t1."AutoLock_LastCheckToTriggerLockTimeSheetCycle", t1."AutoLock_LockTime", t1."AutoLock_SendAfterDays", t1."CycleSetting_EndDay", t1."CycleSetting_IsLastDay", t1."CycleSetting_NumberOfDisplay", t1."CycleSetting_StartDay", t1."Notification_LockNotification", t1."Notification_UnLockNotification"
FROM (
    SELECT o."Id", o."HasInactiveParent", o."HierarchyPath", o."Name", o."OrganizationStatus", o."ParentOrganizationalUnitId", o."RootId"
    FROM (
        SELECT NULL AS empty
    ) AS e
    LEFT JOIN "OrganizationalUnit" AS o ON TRUE
    WHERE (o."Id" = o."RootId" OR ((o."Id" IS NULL) AND (o."RootId" IS NULL))) AND NOT (EXISTS (
        SELECT 1
        FROM "TimeSheetCycle" AS t
        WHERE (o."Id" IS NOT NULL) AND o."Id" = t."CompanyId" AND t."EndDate" >= $1 AND t."StartDate" <= $1))
    ORDER BY o."Id"
    LIMIT $2
) AS t0
LEFT JOIN "TimeSheetSetting" AS t1 ON t0."Id" = t1."CompanyId"
ORDER BY t0."Id", t1."Id" total

targets.rawSql:
select       round(total_time::numeric, 2) as total,
             calls,
             round(mean_time::numeric, 2) as mean,
             stddev_time,
             query_sql_text as query
from query_store.qs_view
where (now() - start_time) <= interval '7 days'
and query_sql_text not ilike '%query_store%'
order by total_time DESC
limit 10;

panels.title: Top 10 most of time in total queries last 7 days

panels.description: Chart will show the top 10 of slowest queries last 7 days

targets.rawSql:
select db_id as database_id, pd.datname, CASE
           WHEN query_sql_text ILIKE 'SELECT%' OR query_sql_text ILIKE '%\n%SELECT%' THEN 'SELECT'
           WHEN query_sql_text ILIKE 'INSERT%' OR query_sql_text ILIKE '%\n%INSERT%' THEN 'INSERT'
           WHEN query_sql_text ILIKE 'UPDATE%' OR query_sql_text ILIKE '%\n%UPDATE%' THEN 'UPDATE'
           WHEN query_sql_text ILIKE 'DELETE%' OR query_sql_text ILIKE '%\n%DELETE%' THEN 'DELETE'
           ELSE 'OTHER'
       END AS query_type, query_sql_text, calls, (total_time/calls)::integer AS avg_time_ms
from query_store.qs_view, pg_database as pd
where db_id = pd.oid and calls > 1000 and query_sql_text not ILIKE '%query_store%'
and (now() - start_time) <= interval '7 days'
ORDER BY avg_time_ms DESC
LIMIT 10;

panels.title: The 10 slowest queries with over a 1000 calls last 7 days

panels.description: Amounts of queries with running longer than 5 minutes last 7 days

targets.rawSql:
SELECT count(*)
FROM pg_stat_activity
WHERE (now() - pg_stat_activity.query_start) > interval '5 seconds' 
AND (now() - pg_stat_activity.query_start) <= interval '7 days'
AND datname NOT ILIKE 'azure_sys';

panels.title: Total queries running longer than 5 sec last 7 days

panels.description:
This chart tell us about what queries is running longer than 5 sec on all database.

#### Please use the *query_type* filter on head of table for get type of queries you want.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  pid,
  datname as database,
  user,
       CASE
           WHEN query ILIKE 'SELECT%' OR query ILIKE '%\n%SELECT%' THEN 'SELECT'
           WHEN query ILIKE 'INSERT%' OR query ILIKE '%\n%INSERT%' THEN 'INSERT'
           WHEN query ILIKE 'UPDATE%' OR query ILIKE '%\n%UPDATE%' THEN 'UPDATE'
           WHEN query ILIKE 'DELETE%' OR query ILIKE '%\n%DELETE%' THEN 'DELETE'
           ELSE 'OTHER'
       END AS query_type,
  pg_stat_activity.query_start,
  now() - pg_stat_activity.query_start AS query_time,
  query,
  state,
  wait_event_type,
  wait_event
FROM pg_stat_activity
WHERE (now() - pg_stat_activity.query_start) > interval '5 seconds' 
AND (now() - pg_stat_activity.query_start) <= interval '7 days'
AND datname NOT ILIKE 'azure_sys';

panels.title: Detail queries running longer than 5 sec on last 7 days

panels.description:
Querying to Check PostgreSQL Open Connections .You need to consider about:

**backend_type** - *Type of current backend*. Possible types are: 

“Client backend" is basically your normal connection from application. All other connections are special processes that “do stuff":

- archiver – runs archive_command (or it's equivalent in newer pgs)
- autovacuum launcher – starts autovacuum workers when it's necessary to vacuum/analyze something
- background writer – writes data to tables/indexes in the background
- checkpointer handles checkpoints – basically every now and then writing all modified data to table/index files
- logical replication launcher – manages processes related to logical replication
- walwriter – writes changes in data to WAL

Aside from these you can also see:

- autovacuum worker – actually does some vacuum/analyze work for autovacuum
- logical replication worker – works on logical replication
- parallel worker – special backend started by client backend where query is being processes in parallel
- startup – applies WAL from somewhere, this is the process that is responsible for recovery and streaming/wal replication
- walreceiver – receives wal stream from source in streaming replication setups
- walsender – sends wal via stream to some replica

You can also see some other types if you use specialized extensions.

*For more detail go to this [link](https://www.depesz.com/2022/07/05/understanding-pg_stat_activity/#:~:text=Last%20column%20is%20backend_type)*

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  COUNT(*) as connections,
  backend_type
FROM
  pg_stat_activity
GROUP BY
  backend_type
ORDER BY
  connections DESC

panels.title: Open Connections

panels.description:
This chart tell about the what active is current running. 
Some of information need to consider:

**State** - *Current overall state of this backend*. Possible values are

- active: The backend is executing a query.
- idle: The backend is waiting for a new client command.
- idle in transaction: The backend is in a transaction, but is not currently executing a query.
- idle in transaction (aborted): This state is similar to idle in transaction, except one of the statements in the transaction caused an error.
- fastpath function call: The backend is executing a fast-path function.
- disabled: This state is reported if track_activities is disabled in this backend.

*For more detail go to this [link](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/monitoring-stats.html#:~:text=Table%C2%A028.13.-,state,-text)*

**Database** - 'some special db you have seen in table chart'
- *postgres* - A default database you can connect to once your server is created.
- *azure_maintenance* - This database is used to separate the processes that provide the managed service from user actions. You do not have access to this database.
- *azure_sys* - A database for the Query Store. This database does not accumulate data when Query Store is off; this is the default setting. For more information, see the [Query Store overview](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/articles/postgresql/single-server/concepts-query-store.md).
panels.title: Process in currently of DB

panels.description: Current infomation about state of process in DB
panels.title: State of process in DB

panels.description:
Currently about the number of application_name in DB. Some situation about the chart:
- If it not exist `application_name`. The `count` column will represent for it.
- The chart will focus visuallize the `application_name` connect what database in `currently` process.
panels.title: Application_name on process in DB

panels.description: Number of connection have blocking by lock

targets.rawSql: SELECT count(distinct pid) FROM pg_locks WHERE granted = false;

panels.title: Connections waiting for a lock

panels.description: Lots of long-running queries can cause your database to be slow or non-responsive.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT count(*) 
FROM pg_stat_activity 
WHERE state != 'idle' 
AND query_start < (NOW() - INTERVAL '60 seconds');

panels.title: Totals queries have been running for longer than a minute

panels.description: Too many write queries to the same (especially large) table can cause lock-contention.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT count(*)  FROM pg_stat_activity
WHERE state != 'idle'
AND query NOT ILIKE '%SELECT%'
AND query ILIKE '%some_big_table%'
AND query NOT ILIKE '%pg_stat_activity%';

panels.title: Total queries are currently writing to the same table

panels.description: Choose the ID in search box variable for get the query

targets.rawSql: SELECT query_sql_text FROM query_store.query_texts_view WHERE query_text_id='$query_current_id';

panels.title: Get query from ID

list.description: ID for select what query text
